div.head: OUR NATIONAL PROSPERITY.
div.p: The figures of our foreign trade for the year, and of our rrevenue for the nine months ending on December 31 enable us to form some estimate of our national prosperity. They are, says the "Spectator," sufficient remarkable to startle even the most optimistic.

For the first time in our history the total volume of oar foreign trade largely, exceeds the enormous figure of one thousand million sterling. Imports have increased by 7.6 per -cent., exports by 13.9 per cent., and the reexport trade by 9.5 per cent To give the figures : — The total value of imports was £607,998,000, an increase of £42,968,000 over those of the preceding-year ; exports reached £375,673,000, an increase of £45,856,000; while re-exports were £85,163,000, an increase of £7,383,000. The details, are as satisfactory as the totals. Among the imports, it is raw material and articles mainly or wholly manufactured in which the chief increase lies, the advance being over 12 per cent. Among the exports, the growing items are largely articles wholly or mainly manufactured, the increase being 13.5 per cent. To take one item, the increase in the export of iron and steel is 25 per cent in value and 26 per cent in quantity.

Nor has the first impression made by these Returns to be corrected by much writing down on account of increased prices. It is true that the prices of many articles and commodities were higher last year than the year before but the general rise in prices is estimated at only 6 per cent, which leaves an ample, margin for quantitative increase. Many conclusions may be drawn from these figures, but one is insistent We are experiencing an unexampled ware of prosperity. Free-trader and Tariff Reformer alike can make but the one deduction. The increase in the imports of raw material and partially manufactured goods, and in the export of wholly or partially manufactured goods, shews that during the past year there has been a high pressure laid upon our producing activity. The demand has forced an expansion of supply. The Tariff Reformer may argue, as the "Times" does, that the dumping of iron has ceased because America is too prosperous and is unable to supply her own requirements, or that we are relieved of some Continental competition because trade is so good with our neighbeurs.The "Spectator" prefers to put it that a general wave of prosperity is passing over the world, and that our existing economic system enables us to take full advantage of it.

The Revenue Returns for the last nine onths are equally comforting. The increase over the corresponding period , in 1905 is £1,497,800. The Chancellor of the Exchequer, having in view the lowering of the duty on tea and the repeal of the duty jon coal, calculated to receive in 1906-7 £1,223.000 less than in. 190545. To take the separate items :— There wqs an estimated decrease of £2,245,000 ip Customs. But up to date the decrease has only been £674,000) and even if wo arsume that this item will decline during the current quarter by another £700,000; the total decrease will still fall far short of the estimate. Excise, estimated to decrease by £30,000, shows for the nine months an increase of £107,000. The Death-duties were, assumed t> grow by £230,000, but the actual growth during threo-querters of the financial year has been £1,495,000. The increase in the Income-tax Returns was patat £150,000 ; it is already £167,000 And in "miscellaneous items" an estimated deficit oh the year of ,£13,000 haa been changed to an increase on the nine months of £336,800. One or two items, such as stamps, show more than their eitimated decrease, and-it looks as if the Post Office and Telegraph receipts might fall short of their estimated increase. But these are minor figures com paled with the great totals of incroase. Mr Asquith can scarcely avoid having in hand at the end.of the financial year a balance over his estimates of something between £2,000,000 and £3,000,000, and if he succeeds in effecting certain savings in expenditure, as seems probable, he may have a surplus of from £6,000,000 to £6,000.000 At present, of course, the trade prosperity is not lully rejected in the Revenue Returns, except to some small degree in Customs. But a prosperous commerce, high wages, and continuous employment are bound very-soon to give a new elasticity to the revenue and next year we may look to see its effects. It is true that the enormous receipts from .Death-loties last year were rather in the bature of a windfall, arid that millionaires cannot be expected to die with such regularity and profusion in every financial year. The objection is fair, but it must not be pressed too for. It seems to us that evegy Chancellor of the Exchequer is justified in Hooking for much larger receipts from the Death-duties during he coming decade than have accrued during he past The great fortunes have been most f them made within the last thirty years, and heir possessors are only just beginning to dirt Ve should not be surprised to see the Death-utiea double their yield during the next wenty years.

div.head: Quarantine In Turkey.
div.p: A telegram from Constantinople states that arrivals from Port Said are subject to a medical examination.

div.head: Council of Ministers.
div.p: The Council of Ministers will meet on Tuesday aftenoon at Aberdeen Palace under the presidency of the Khedive.

div.head: The Weather.
div.p: Owing to the high sea running outside the harbour pass, bessels were unable to enter the port this afternoon. The black flag is flying over Komel Nadoura, which indicates that the pilot cannot leave the harbour.

div.head: Visit of Japanese Squadron.
div.p: A Japanese Squadron which is on its way to Great Britain on an official visit is due at Suez in the early party of February. It is not yet known whether the Admiral and his staff will go to Cairo to be received by the Khedive.

div.head: Five Days on a Desert Island.
div.p: An Ottoman sailing ship which lately left this port for Scio, in ballast was surprised by a squall and sunk off the isle of Poffs. The master and crew of six reached shore in the ship's boat. The islet is barren and for five days they were without food. They were picked up by a saiiling ship from Simi.

div.head: Kourban Beyram.
div.p: The Ministry of War has issued orders for salnes to be fired on Wednesday afternooon, and on each of the following four days, on the occasion of Kourban Beyram The Khedive will attend Beyraum prayers early on Thursday morning at Koub eh Mosque. A salute of 21 guns will the be fired from the Citadel and Abbassieh barracks.

div.head: Arrival of Caronia.
div.p: The Cunard liner Caronia arrived here on Saturday afternoon from New York and Naples, with a large number or tourists. A special train was in waiting on the quay and left at 6 p.m. for Cairo with most of the passengers; others left for Palestine by the Khedivial Mail steamer, while a few preferred to remain in Alexandria. The Caronia sailed yesterday at 3 p.m. for New York via Fiuume and Naples.

div.head: EDUCATION IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Alured Bell write to the "Morning Post": Sir,- As your interesting interview with Mr. Sidney Wellls the new Director-General of education in Egypt, throws a good deal of light on one department of the British administation, may I be permitted the opportunity of emphasising a few points necessarily ignored io the impres-ionist opinion of a stranger to the country.

Tha national good wishes wi1l, accompany the ex Principal of the Battersen Polytechnic in his mission for the advancement of the Egyptian youth in technical education, but it is no disparagement to him to say that no new mantle can overshadow the remarkable education regime instituted by Lord Cromer in 1890, and conducted with conspicnous success by Mr. Donglas Dunlop, the Inspector General of Egyptian Education. I remember the time when, for instance, the proportion of pupils in tte Government schools learning French and English was, respectively. 80 and 20 per cent.; it is now, I believe. the other way round, namely, 15 and 85 per cent, in favour ot tha English language. All the superior colleges of which Mr. Wells speaks, such as the Schools of Agriculture, Law, Medicine, and Engineering, have been founded under the "old" regime, and Lord Cromer has given expression to his innate missionary genius in promoting the entirely un-Mohamedan cult of female education by establishing schools for Egyptian girls. The progress of the Egyptian youth in technical educaiton is, in my humble opinion, of far less moment than their progress in morality, logic, citizenship, and government, and the basis of these things has been well and truly laid during the last sixteen years. As a proof of this I would advance the improvement in the character of the Egyptian Government employees, the great increase in the publishing and clientele of native newspapers, and the really remarkable tendency in the higher social circles towards monogamy and the disuse of female seclusion.

The influence of the Oxford and Cambridge graduates whom Mr. Dunlop has gathered round him as professors in the schools cannot be overestimated-it is as real and permanent an influence as that acknowledged of his own masters by the English public school boy. In a word deep inroads have been made in the Oriental habit-of thought; Western, even British, ideas have been inculcated; and it is on this groundwork that Mr. Wells will construct his superior technical edifice. Lest he should, in his enthusiasm, be too anxious for immediate results, may I venture to remind him of the Arab proberb, "Harry is the Devil, slowness is of God."

div.head:
KIAMIL PASHA'S CASE.
MUSSULMANS AND BRITAIN.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)
LONDON January 21.

The "Times" commenting on Kiamil Pasha's dismissal, remarks that the fact of the late Grand Vizier's taking refuge in the British Consulate at Smyrnam and the Sultan according to British demands for his safety affordss striking tribute to British reputataion amoung the Muasnlman population. The "Spectator" says that this shows that the British flag is still regarded in the Turkish Empire aas a protection to those standing in fear of injustice.
CONSTANTINOPLE January 20.
Kimil Pasha has arrived and went straight to Yildiz Kiosk. Haveas

The reasons to which our Stamboul Correspondent attributes the dismissal of the Vali of Aidin are that his son, Rear-Admiral Said Pasha now in exile at Jerusalem, corresponded with brigands in the bilayet, a state of things which Kiamil Pasha was too old to prevent.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN UNIVERSITY.
div.p: Kassim Bey Assem, acting president of the committee of the proposed university, informed the committee at their meeting on Saturday that the Khedive had graciously agreed to place the cheme under his Highness's patronage, and to appoint the Heir Apparent as honorary president of the committee, promising to select a Price of the Khedivial family as president. The committee is receiving small subscription from the pupils of Government schools.

div.head: PRINCE OF UDINA'S VISIT
div.p: H.R.H. the Prince of Udina attended the performance of "Gli Ugonotti" on Saturday evening at the Zizinia Theatre being accomodated in the box of H.E. the Governor, who was also present. After the performance his Royal Highness was the guest of the Governor at supper at the New Khedivial Hotel. Marquis di Soragno, the Italian Consul, Chabalier Morenco, commandmant of the ornier Calabria, and the Beneduccdi Bey secretary to the Governor. were also the guests of Mustapha Pa-ha Ibady.

As already announced an "At Home" will be given by the Italian colony in Alexandria at 5 p.m. or Friday next at the New Khedivial Hotel in honour of the Prince of Udina and the officers of the Calabria.

div.head: FUNERAL OF DEAN BUTCHER.
div.p: Manifestations of the deepest sympathy marked the funeral of the late Dean Butcher on Saturday At 3 p.m. the coffin, wrapped in the Union Jack, was borne on the shoulders of eight men of the Intri-killing Fusiliers from Church House to the proch of Al Saints' Church, and was carried to the charcoal, preceded by the choir, while "Oh rest in the Lord" E.j.b) was played. After the effident was placed in the chanc flowers were strewn on it by the ladies of the choir, and hun No. 508 was sure, followed by the 90th psalm. The R v. J. T Burns read the lesson from Corinthane, after which "Nune Dimittis" was sung, and the congregation stood while the Dead March in Sanl was played. On leaving the church the coffin was placed on a gun carriage and drawn by black horses and preceded by an escort of Military Mounted Police. On its arrival at the cemetery eight men of the K.O.S.B. carried the coffin to the graveside, preceded by the choir singing "Now the labourer's task is o'er." The enmmittal service was conducted by Bishop Ridley, sud on its conclusion the members of the choir dropped sprigs of cypress on the coffin, and then sang as a recessional, "On the Resurrection Morning." The chief mourners were Mrs. Butcher who was accompanied by Mr. Dou Boulay, and Mr. and Mrs. Possman. Many beautiful wreaths were sent, and the services, both at All Saint's and at the cemetary, were attended by nearly all the British residents of Cairo and several members of the Coptic churches.

div.head: NEW BANK FOR CAIRO.
div.p: Yet another new bank is, we learn, about to be established in the Capital. Mr. Ben Lassin, who has been iin the employ of the Anglo Egyptian Bacnk for the past ten years, and who was lately acting as assistant manager in Cairo, is servering his connection with that bank next month and opening a private banking firm with a capital of L.E. 100,000 in conjunction with Mr. Maurice Ades. of Mesra. Mansour & Ades, and Mr. Humbert Jabes, of Messrs. Haim Jabes & Figli.

div.head: MR. Robertsono, M.P.
div.p: Mr. J.M. Robertson, M.P., visited the Ministry of Education on Saturday, and had an interview with Mr. Dunlop, Adviser to the Ministry, and Mr. Boyd Carpenter, inspector. Afterwards he visited the Nasrieh school, and had a long converstaion with the headmaster of the latter. In the afternoon the M.P. wernt to Mastariahm where he took the house of Saved Hassan Moussa. El-Akkad. Mr. Robart on yesterday visited some other school kutabs in Cairo belonging to the government.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN AGITATION.
div.p: YESTERDAY'S SCENES IN ALEXANDRIA.

To all outward appearance, Alexandria, ordinarily is peaceful on a Sunday, seemed yesterday to be in the very throes of a revolution. The agitation in favour of the release of three Russian refugees, who have been arrested by the police on a very grave charge, and to which we referred on Saturday, yesterday assumed much more serious proportions than were warranted by the facts of the cave. Reedless of the diplomatic difficulties which stand in the way of such a step, and regardless of the Capitulations, a large proportion of the European population of Alexandria is clamouring for the release of thrre Russian revolutionaries, whose extradition they wish to prevent—on grounds which are purely sentimental. However much we may sympathise with the Russian revolutionaries in their strnggle with despotism, any movement such as the present is greatly to be deprecated, and we are surprised to see that a local contemporary has gone to such extreme lengths in fanning an agitation which can be prodcotive ol no good.
The scenes in the streets of Alexandria both on Saturday and yesterday were deplorable.

On Saturday, on a rumour being spread that the refugees had been embarked on the Russian steamer for Odessa, a crowd of'manifestanta" nade their way to the quay, shouting "Vive la liberty," and boarded the vessel with the object of discovering whether the rumour was true. As it happened it was not, but some ill-advised person in authority called out the Pire Brigade to deal with the demonstrators. This measure only aggravated the situation, and gave rise to incidents which might have been avoided by the exercise of more discretion. The crowd attacked the Fire Brigade and did some damage to the engine and hoses, while some horse play was indulged in. Order was only restored by the arrival of H B. the Governor, who gave his personal assurance that the prisoners were safe in custody, and that they would not bo deported before a full enquiry was held into the case.

Yesterday something of the natnre of an attack was made on the Russian Consulate in Ramleh-boulevard, ths consulate shield being torn down. A cordon of police was afterwards formed round the consulate and traffic stopped iu that part if the boalevard. The efforts ot the police to keep people away from the vicinity of the building resulted in several scuffles, but nothing of a very serious character happened, and after nightfall the street returned its normal aspect, two sentries being left posted at the consulate door. Several demonstrations took plsce in various parts if the city daring the day, no'allly at the Bourse, where M Alfred Campos, as one of the leaders of the agitation, connseled calm, wisely stating that their object could not be attained by resort to force but by peaceful means.

Meantime the prisoners are incarcerated at Hadra prison, awaiting the decision of the authorities. We believe that a solution of the dlfficulty will be foundd in their being sent to one European port.

div.head: Zizinia Theatre
div.p: Meyervere's fine old opera "Qli Ugnnotti" was very well given on Saturday night: it was the high level of the performances which we have yet seen. Sig. Marchi Emilio is a most sympathetic Reoul, and, though laboring ' under 'he disadvantage of a heavy cold, filled his exacting part admirably. We hope to see no more empty houses during his adjourn in Alexandria. Signs. de Lerma Matilde's Valentins is a convincing combination ' of voice and acting ; and her difficult and involved gymnastics in the opper compass were most cleverly and accurately handled by Sig Finizi Magrini. We will not deny, however, that we feel, as it were, born out of due time for there intricate cadences, which give one, like the longer trills in Handel's Messiah, no definite pleasure, but rather a hauting terror that the strained performer will break down, turning pathos into bathos. For the rest, Siz. Chotkowska Ladislawa made I an attractive Urbano and as for Marcello—

we are almost tired of praising Sig. Walter Carlo, who never disappoints us. The orchestra ' showed to great advantage, especially in the difficult viola passages in Act I ; and here , at the risk of boring by repeated insistence on our point, we cannot help remarking once again that we do not want to hear either the conductor's mellow tones or the innuating asides of the prompter; singly, they are distictly audible in unison, they carry all before them.
again that we do not want to hear either the condootor's mellow tones or the indnuatiog asides of the prompter ; singly, they are di-tinotly audib'e;iu unison, thry carry all btfire them.

div.head: TRIPOLI IN BARBARY.
div.p: The administrative and financial reorganization of the sanjak of Benghzi has been decided on. THe eight nahiehs into which the sarjak is divided are to be abolished, and three xazas and a new nahieh will be formed in their stead. A special corps of five inspectors and fifty tax collectors will be appointed to replace the present fiscal system which the sarjak enjoy.

div.head: CAIRO'S GARDEN CITY.
div.p: Several of the very best plots of this estate are offered, at very reasonable rates, by Mr. C. Aquilina, Carlton Hotel, Bulkeley.

div.head: Winter Palace Hotel
div.p: LUXOR'S NEW HOSTERLY.
(From Our Special Correspondent.)
Luxor Monday.

Tha inaugural proceeding at the new Winter Palace Hotel have been carried out with such delightful entertainment and on such a lavish scale that everyone who has partaken of the hospitality offered him is filled with regret at their termination. Saturday's programme included the visit to the far famed Tombs of the Kings for those who were energetically inclined, and a most perfect lunch was served to those who preferred to spend their morning exploring the various objects ot interest in the immediate neighbourhood.

During the afternoon the workmen and builders who had labored so conscientiously at their task were collected in the still unfinished garden at the back of the hotel and there received the reward of their toil in the shape of most congratulatory speeches from Mr. E. A. Harrison and Mr. Splenon and substantial gifts, doles of meat being distributed to the men and handsome watches being presented to those who had control of the various gangs. Mr. Harrison indeed proved the presiding spirit at these, as at the subsequent proceedings, being generous in the thanks he accorded to those who had borne the burden and heat of the day, and hospitable to a degree to all who, were present. As chairman of the Upper Egypt Hotels Co., he voiced his committee in its expression of hope for a successful future. Mr. Harrison has assuredly done his best to make that future a certainty. The dinner hour was fixed for 7.30 pm., and the restaurant, brilliantly lighted and tastefully decorated, was soon filled with guests. A long T-shaped table was surrounded by notabilities from Cairo and the neighbourhood and representatives of the press. We have not space to give the names of those who were present. Enough that the dinner was admirable, and the future visitors of the hotel should have the utmost confidence in the cuisine. Speeches, dancing, bridge, and conversation followed the dinner, and in the course of the whole of our Egyptian experience we have never known an evening in which hospitality and informality were so delightfully blended, and we have no hesitation in saying that if the Winter Palace Hotel continues as it has begun it will be the most popular house of entertaiment in the length and breadth of Egypt. The only cause for regret during the above-mentioned proceedings was the absence of M. Pagnon, who, as proprietor of Pagnon's Hotels and latterly as managing director of the Upper Egypt Hotels, has proved himself to be one of the leading and most successful personalities in Egypt.

div.head: TOWN TEEMING WITH TOURISTS.
div.p: Luxor is awake! The town teems with tourists. Dahavashs are daily arriving. The Luxor and Savoy Hotels are full, and the steamers of Messra. Thos. Cook and Son and the Hamburg and Anglo-American Companies line the river wharves, bearing their full complement of passengers, and making the froont hum with life.

Before these lines are in print, another will be added to the list of hostelries at this popular resort, and the "Winter Palace Hotel" will have started on its career. The bookings for rooms are numerous, and the manager looks forward confidently to a successful and a long continued season.

The weather has been delightful. Even during the heat-wave that prevailed further South a short time ago Luxor escaped it's intenisity, and now the north wind has arrived, and, after a short break, the sun is once more tempering its keenness, and warming the air as only Egyptian sunshine in January can. It is well known to visitors who come to Luxor again and again, that here is no climate of extremes. It is unusual to have either intensely hot, or very cold weather, during the winter season, and its situation is particularly sheltered from high winds.

Regular weekly Gymkhanas are now being held on the race-course just outside the town. The third meeting of the season, on Thursday last, was a most successful one. The usual native races were much appreciated by the many strangers who filled the the grand-stand, while the three races for visitors: gentlemen's donkey race, ladies' race, and goolsh-pegging were well patronised and caused much amusement both for riders and spectators. Baron Heintze, a well known visitor to Luxor, carried off the 1st prize at the goolabs, and was also second in the donkey race.

A very enjoyable entertainment was given on Thurdsay evening on board the Rameses III., when some extremely clever tricks of cards and sleight of-hand were shown by Sir Alfred Cooperm who is making the Nile trip with his son. Some charming music was also provided, the singing of Miss Reibold being a specially great treat to those privileged to hear her. A collection was made at the end of the evening for the Luxor Hospital for natives, which will no doubt benefit to a considerable exxtent by the happy thought of those who organised the show.

Among the visitors now at the Luxor Hotel are Bishop and Mrs. Whitehead of Madras, who are making a stay in Egypt on their way to India, and Sir Benjamin Stone, M.P. for East Birmingham, and well-known as a traveller and as a clever and enthusiastic photographer.

div.head: FAYOUM RACES
div.p: F.R.C.'s FIRST MEETING.
(From Our Correspondent.)

THe first meeting of the Fayoum Racing Club on their new course took place on Friday, and proved an unqualified success, the attendance being extremely large and some 42 horses entering for the five races on the programme. Amon those present were the Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior and Lady Vicotira Machell, Captain Proheroe Smisth and practically all the Englishmen connected any way with the province; while of the native notables frew if any were absent.
The club has erected two pulbic stands and a third class enclosure, besides a private stand; stalls are provided for 30 houses and a parimutual and a buffet are included.

Anybody in serach of a boy who can ride 5 stone would find a treasure in the rider of the winner of the third and fourth races. Though conly a small Sudannee boy of 10 years he rides with all the confidence of a crack light weight at home, and with no little judgment. The following were the resutls of the races:-
The Karoun Stakes value P.T. 800.
Abdul Wahed and Ahmed Fathi's Gazelle Mahomed Salah's Matrowie Mahomed Basil's Assiury
13 started. Won easily by three length. The Club Stakes. value P.T. 600. Abdul Washed and Ahmed Fatbi's Fritz Moward O'eilb's Kaahf
Shek Yesseen Abouel Mckaram's Tyar 6 ran. Fritz made practically all the running and won in a canter by three lengths.
The Fayoum Stakes value P.T. 2500.
Mahomed el Basil's Fayoum 1
Mahomed Salah's Matrowie 2
Mahomed Abdul Hallaq's Farhan 3

5 ran. At the end of the first mile Matrowie seemed to have the race in hand, catching up the leaders when akad without apparent effort, but entering the straight Fayoum drew further away at every stride and won as he liked by 8 lengths.
The Pyramid Stakes value P.T. 1,000.
Mohamed Amin's Maurice 1
Moward Koleib's Ka-hf 2
Homamed Aly Byad's Kouisan

9 ran. a very hot pace soon produced a long tail with Kousan leading; in the straight Kashf and Maurice both passed him, and maintaining his effort the latter won a good race all out by a length and a half.

The fifth race somewhat failed in its object, it being intended for bona fide fellaheen, with a special prize to the omdeh of the village from which the winning horse came. Unfortunately I became known that the Moudir had presented a gold watch for the winning omdeh, and though three horses were sent back at the post out of the 15, the first three horses in the race should also have been disqualified. Many difficulties occurred, but the prizes were eventually awarded them.

The thank of the committee are especially due to Lady Victoria Machell for kindly distributing the prizes, to the Moudir for his constant supervision of the arrangements, and to Ahmed Eff Farhion whom most of the work has fallen Mr. Miller kindly acted as starter, and Captain Prothero Smith as judge.

Our correspondent at Medinatel Fayoum compalins of the indolence of the Municipality whose intertia is responsible for the lack of drinking water. He suggests artesian wells to replace the present supply of stagnant water. The native members of the Municipality, he says, do not pay much attention to sanitary rules, and their European colleagues have no time to see the city's welfare.
Bountiful rains have fallen in the Fayoum, and the crops have benefited thereby.
Upwards of twelve thousand men are engaged on contract works in the province.
During 1906 the Fayoum branch of the Agricultural Bank received about L.E. 38000, and the Cre lit Foncier and other tanks collectiverly L.E. 50,000

Our Correspondent remarks upon M. Machell's great popularity in the Fayoum. The Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior held a reception there last wekk, and afterwards visited the districs of Abexa, Abbhsway and Shwashia. He was acompanied by Lady Victoria Machell.
A Kassala correspndent states that measles are still raging in the lines of the 11th Battalion, about 75 children suffering from the disease. In the town only one case is reported.
The Gash cultivation is at its, especially the cotton cultivation. The pre eat price is P.T. 80 per kantar.
Mr. Tottenham, Inspector of Irrigation, arrived in Kassala on the 28th ulto in order to organize this year's operations.

The American Admiral at the request of the British authorities has landed marines. The streets are picketed with American guars. 600 bodies have now been recovered and more are constantly brought to light.
Both the Prinz Waldemar and the Prinz Eitel Friedrich, of the Hamburg American Line, are ashore on the coast of Jamaica. It is supposed that this happened owiing to submarine changes in the channel.

(Later). Over 700 bodies have now been bnried. The American marines are busy destroying dangerous buildings by dynamite. The inhabitants are most grateful to the United States for her assistance. No British vessels have arrived. There are 20,000 people homeless and destitute. (Feuter)
A volcano has sprouted to the north of Jamaica, and has caused numerous casualties.
(Havas)

The United States fleet leaving owing to a peremptory letter from the Governor of the Island requesting their withdrawal, on the ground of being fully able to attend to all the needs of the population.

He was only willing to permit a party of unarmed Americans to land to protect the Consulate. Tbe American Admiral declared that the immediate departure of the vessels was the only course confident with the dignity of the United States.

The last accounts show that the death roll was under-estimated. In addition to 700 bodies already buried, there are over 1000 un-identified dead still unburied, while the number of injured is estimated at 3,000. of whom about 1,000 are seriously injured. (Reuter)

div.head:
CORONATION OF SHAH.
HEIR APPARENT NOMINATED.

div.p: The Shah has ascended the peacock throne.The late Shah's second son has been appointed Heir Apparent. The Princes, Ministers, and diplomatists were present at the entbronement. The Grand Vixier placed the crown on the Shah's head. Tbe British and Russian Ministers subsequently expressed the satisfaction of the sovereigns at the nomination of the Heir Apparent, which is regarded as assuring permanent order in Persia. (Reuter)

The city was illluminated yesterday evening, when general public rejoicing took place. The Shah, this morning, held his first reception in the palace court. He sat upon the marble throne and the Heir Apparent stood in froot of him. (Reuter)
The bishops have sent an address to the Pope concurring completely in the judgment given by His Holiness respecting the separation laws. (Reuter)
The assembly of French Bishops has decided to maintain the status quo for religious servances. (Haros)
A collision has occurred between a passenger and a goods train at Fowler (Indiana) 8 persons have been killed and 15 incinerated in the wreckage. (Reuter)
Signor Saracco, ex-Premier, is dead. (Seuter)

div.head:
GERMAN SOCIALISM.
PRINCE BULOW'S ELECTIONEERING SPEECH.

div.p: Prince von'Bulow, departing from all precedent, delivered a regular electioneering speech at a banquet at which he was entertained by a political committee. The decision of German electors in favour of international and social democracy, he said, would insure the prestige of the Imperial Government and the peace of the German people.

He regarded the events of the 12th December as the turning point in the national life, because they witnessed the union of the conservatives and liberals in defence of the colonies and setup a precedent for dealing with other great national issues. It was narrow egoism which induced the centrist and revolutionary members to join the Socalists. The despotism and arrogance of the Socialist leaders sought to choke all cooperation which would result in positive reform. How 1ong, he said will this slavery of millions of German workers endure? (Reuter)

div.head:
TO DEAL WITH THE LORDS.
SPEECH BY MR. BIRREL.

div.p: Mr. Birrel speaking at Bristol, said that before many moths the Government would resubmit education plans to the House of Lords to enable the latter to reconsider their judgement. The Govern,emt must also consider the problem too long postponed of dealing with the Lords. We must have, he said, a Second Chamber which the country can respect. (Reuter)

div.head:
JAPS IN SAN FRANCISCO
FEDERAL GOVERNMENT'S ACTION.

div.p: The Federal Government has started two actions in San Francisco to ensure for the Japanese equal advatages with regard to the schools question. It contends that the exclusion of their children is a flagrant violation of the treaty not justified by the law of California, and if it is justified the law will be made null and void. (Reuter)
The Government will address a Note to the Powers, in conccert with Spain, recording the success of intervention in Morocco and announcing the withdrawal of the squadrons. (Hacas)
Some disturbances took placce heere in connection with sunday closing. The police made many arrests, nine of which were maintained. (Havas)
A girl has been arrested in a station of the Visinla railway in Poland carrying four bombs each containing five poinds of Melinite, under her petticoat. (Reuter)
The P. and O. Moldavia is ashore on the Goodwin Sand abreast of the Deal Pier. The captain reports that he does not require assistance.
(Later). The Maldavia has been reflated and is proceeding on her journey. She has sustained no damage. (Reuter)

div.head: THE EL KEBIR.
div.p: Historical events have succeeded one another so rapidly the last few years in Egypt that even the details ot the bombardment in Alexandria and the misadventure of Arabi Pasa have passed away into the realms of ancient history save to those who were personally interested in them. Scarce a dozen pilgrims in as many years ever visit thus forgotten battlefield of Kassassin and Tel el Kebir unless it be those who still mourn for their dead at rest in the little cemetery in the vicinity. The mail train between Cairo and Port Saidd screeches as it dashes past the deserted stations ; but so far has Tel el. Kehi sunk back into the obscurity from which it emerged for that short space of time in 1882 that it is difficult enongh to arrive there unless one leaves Cairo at the early hour of 7 a.m., and the little journey of some forty miles takes at least two hours to cover. The village itself lies some distance away from the station on the further side of the freshwater canal which has played so important a part in the history of the century and the few cottages and native shops which have sprung up round the station do not argue much for the prosperity of the place.

Within a five minutes' walk, alongside the railway track, surrounded by a high fencing and embowered among its plantation of cypress, eucalyptus, and palm trees, is the pathetic little cemetery where so many a young and promising life was laid to its eternal rest. Wander through it now, and even after twenty five long years, its gravestones will still touch some faint chord of memory and stir the heart anew. Here Major Strong, of the R.M.L.I. is buried, and here also is the grave of Colonel Beasley of the R.D. Fasiliers. Lieut. J. A. Park and Lieut. G. McNeill, both of the 42nd Royal Highlanders, sleep their long last sleep in close proximity; and the grave of Lieut. L. Somerville is also nearby. Among the graves of the rank and file are those of the Gordon Highlander, 4th Dragon Guardl 1st Life Guards, 4th Highlanders 1st Cameron Highalnder, 2nd Coldstream Guard, and King's Royal Rifles; some with memorial tablets erected by their comrades, some with individual head stone, some, also marked by the simple cross dedicated to the "One Unknown." Muhamedans do not enter this little enclosure; and though it has but few visitors of any sort, it shows signs of careful tending which are grateful enough even to the casual Englishman who wanders thus far from the beaten track, and should be doubly to those whose near and dear ones lie there enshrined.

The battlefield where Arabi made his last stand lies some three miles away, between the railway and canyon now levelled and turned into fertile soil where the Egyptian Government is making offreating experiments. But for this plants and the qalavated fields around it and the two hundred at the site, the battlefield lies just as it was left after those eventful days of the autumn ot '82. Walking around the hummocks of hard and stony desert which border the railway, one can form a fairly good idea of that forced march taken by our troops between the setting and up rising sun which so covered them with glory at the time. Here can still be traced the lines of earthwork- occupied by Arabi and his troop when he fell back from Kasassiu ; here are the very embrasures of his guns just as they were aft when that overpowering charge of British troops ruhei his positions, and drove the rebel army back into the Delta. Mount this line of earthworks which still meander round the position and imagine be scene for a moment. the 30,000 regular and irregular native troops safe as they thought in their entrenchments; the first streaks of dawn just apperaing in the sky. Then the sudden and unexpected approach of the British the first warning crack of an Egyptian rifle and the the sudden cheer and rush of our men as they charged across the field, Highlanders well to the fore. Imagine the pouring forth of smoke and flame from the trenches, imagine the mees as the rebels were pushed back and back into the second line of the earthworks and then finally were scattered into the desert. The engagement was short sure and sharp and decisive and that subsequent hurried march of the British troops acroos the intervening country to Cairo broke the back of the rebellion. And even though the details of the fight becaee lost in the mist of years, and history books are but dull reading, it is gross for us to stand there on the very spot and think of the days that are gone.

So fot a quarter of a century this battlefield has remained as it was left on that event! day of September 13th, 1882, perhaps its very isolation the most eloquent memorial of the engagement. Who knows but in this course of time its site may be lost under the fields of vegetation which little by little are lapping at its boundaries. For with the increasing prosperity of the country and the spread of Cairo's suburbs, it is not at all improbable that the wonderful climate of Tel-el-K ebir will build it another reputation in the future.

Certain it is that that this neighborhood was the Goshen of the Bible: here Joseph dwelt with his family and flock; and here later on the Hebrews lived out their dreadful bondage, building treasure cities and stone-houses for their royal masters. Remains of these grain stories have been discovered within recent years, and it supposed that the neighbouring ruins of Telle Makhuts probably mark the site of the Biblical Pithoun.

But at the present there are but few signs of prosperity about the surrounding county. Though every year sees more land under cultivation. Few trains stop at the little station, andd the intending pilgrim must make up his mind for an early start if he wishes to return by the train which leaves Tel-el-Kebir at 4.15 p.m. And as there is absoultely no accommodation of restaurant or the like, he must necessarily bear with him all he is likely to require. But beyond these drawbacks and verily ther are scarcely hardships if taken in the right way, a day spent in the glorious keen dessert air on a spot rich with historical associations is of far more value to mind and body than many passed amid the more vitiating surroundings of town life.

div.head: DR. WILLIAMS PINK PILLS.
div.p: " 'How pale and bloodless she looks' was the expression I often heard as I passed through the streets," said Mrs. Annie Preston, who when interviewed at 26, Wellington street, Stott Hill, Bradford, recalled the time of intense suffering that darkened her existence yet to day Mrs. Preston is well, happy and ective, and for this restoration she gives every credit to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills.
"As a girl,: she said, "I was always-pale and delicate, so muchh so that when in company I became quite ashamed of my deathly pallor
"But this was not my worst trouble. My eyes became sunken and glassy, my gums white, and my tongue discoloured. Then I lost all vitality and strength; my breath was short and painful.
Stabbing Pains of Indigestion

attacked me in the chest after every meal until eventually I dreaded the sight or smell of food even such simple diet as bread and butter produced a distressing fulness, followed by a lurking sensation.
"My head was racked with pains across my forehead, and my right grew dim; many times during the day I felt a reeling sensation overcome me.

'My whole body became weak and languid and the slightest exertion excited pain. My deep at night was broken, and in the morning I would rise feeling dead tired and unfit for anythin. Breakfast was always left untouched except perhaps a cup of tea.
'All interest in life disappeared, and anemia so ravaged my system that I really
Looked years older than I was.
My nerves became unstung, and my hands tumbled so violently that I could not hold a tea cup.
"If I went upstairs I was attacked by cruel palpitation of the heart and loss of breath, and felt so puffed out that I frequently collapsed and remained there until assistance came.
"So seriously did these symptoms develop that at last I was red iced to a skeleton, and inked like a girl in the last stages of commotion.

"It was only when I was verging on despair that my mother insisted tha*. I should try Dr. Williams Pink Pills. I began them, and after a time I could tell that slowly but surely a marvelous change was coming over me. When I had emptied ths third box I even began to take a little solid food, which I digested readily. Then I found my strength was being built up rapidly I regained my height my origin spirits and lost my haggard appearauoe. I continued to mend, and in two mouths felt
Quits Myself Again.

with my nerves so strong that I always felt well. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People dispersed all traces of anemia with the terrible palpitations and feeling of utter exhaustion ; more than that they built up my health and strength until 1 became as hearty and active as you see me now."

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN LAND INVESTMENT AND BUILDING
div.p: Company, Limited.
Registered under the Companies' Acts, 1862 to 1900.
The subscription list will open at the Bank of Athens at Cairo and Alexandria on Monday. the 21st day of January, 1907, and will close on WEDNESDAY, the 23rd day of JANUARY, 1907.
Capital.. 300,000
Divided into 298,000 Ordinary Shares of 1 each, and 40,000 Deferred Shares of 1s. each.

The Ordinary Share, are entitled to dividends , in priority to the Deferred Shares up to 7 percent. out of the profits available for distribution as dividend in each year, and subject thereto and after payment of the Directors' additional remuneration, to 60 percentt, of the profits thereafter available for distribution as dividend in each year, the Deferred Shares being entitled, to the remainder. In the event of the winding up of the Company. the Capital paid up or credited as paid up on the Ordinary Shares soil he repaid in priority to that paid up or credited as paid up on the Deferred Shares. Any surplus assess remaining aftor repayment of the Capital paid up or credited as paid up, I will be divided as to 60 per cent, among the Ordinary Shares and as to the remainder among the Deferred Shares.
The Directors now offer for subscription at ls premium 100,000 Ordinary Shares, payable as follows : —
28. per share on Application ;
4s, per share on Allotment;
5s. one month after Allotment.
and the balance as required in installments not exceeding 5s. each, and at intervals of not less than one month.
The premiums will be appropriated towards the payment of the preliminary expenses and the underwriting commision.
Share warrants to bearer will be issued if required after the shares are fully paid, to original subscribers free of stamp duty.
Directors.
NeoHib Eid, Landed Proprietor, Cairo. Akhnoukh Fanous Lu ded Proprietor Assiont. Jean Joannides, General Manager, Bank of Athens in Egypt, Alexandria.
Robert Scott. late Egyptian Manager at Cairo the Gre-ham Life Assurance Society, Limited. Cairo, Managing Director.
Henri Steinemann Merchant, of Messrs, Steinemann, Mabardi & Co, Alexandria, Bankers.
The Bank of Athens, Cairo and Alexandria, Solicitors.
Cutler A. Jones 10 George Yard, Lombard Street, London E.C.
Legal Adviser in Egypt.
Frederick Eveaux, 9 Rue de Eglise Deblane, Alexandria.
Auditors
Russell. Kerr & Wyatt. Cairo, Alexandria, and Moorgate Court, Moorgate StreB*, London, B. C.
London Secretary and Offices..
L. A. Benham, Suffik House, Laurence Pountney Hill. London. E.C.
Office in Cairo.
6, Sharia Cherf , Cairo.

This Company has been formed for the purpose of acquiring and developing land, industrial and other undertakings in Egypt, the Sudan and elsewhere, including the securing of land concessions and the development of building estates as set out in its Memoraudum ol Association.

The investment of money in Egyptian properties since the completion of the International Agreements has led to very satisfactory results, and the expansion and growth of industrial enterprise which has now set in, presents most favorable opportunities for participating in the further impending developments on very promising conditions.
The Board of Directors propose to direct their attention more particularly to the purchase and development of building land and its division into plots and: heir subsequent leasing or re-sale.

Amongst other remunerative methods of dealing with properties which may be acquired is the erection of houses and other building. and the re-sale of them on the installment system. As is well known, the demand for residential premier in the principal towns of Egypt is far in excess of the supply, and the Directors propose to take up business of the forgoing nature and anticipate a considerable demand from Purchasers on the installment system and otherwise.

The value of land in Egypt is shown by the sales which are taking place et constantly enhanced prices, and it is believed that the Board of Directors will be able to obtain, through their intimate local knowledge, exceptional opportunities of securing properties which will greatly increase in value at an early date, quite independent of the development works which may be undertaken.
The Directors have already received several business propositions, which or some of which they believe to be of a most favorable nature.
There, will come under their consideration after the first general allotment of shares, and as negotiations will then have to be entered into, details cannot now be given.

The Company has secured the services as Managing Director of Mr. Robert Scott of Cairo, late Egyptian Manager of the Gresham Life Assurance Society, Ltd., together with the cooperation, on tie Board of Directors, of the other gentlemen named, all of whom have resided in Egypt for a number of years and who are well in touch with the class of business with which the Company will deal.
The amount fixed by the Artioles of Association as the minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is ten per cent of the share offered for subscription.
The preliminary expenses are estimated at £ 3,500 (exclusive of the underwriting comission).
Share Warrants to bearer will be issued if required, after the shares are fully paid, to original subscribers free of stamp duty.
The following information is given to comply with the provisions of the Companies' Act, 1900:—

Art. 101. — Each Direotor shall be entitled to be paid out of the funds of the Company remuneration for his services at the rate of £200 per annnur, with an additional £100 per annum for the Chairman of the Board. The Directors shall also be entitled as additional remuneration to 5 percent. of the profits of the Company in each year available for dividend remaining afterpayment of the 7 percent. preferential dividend on the Ordinary Shares. All such additional remuneration shall be divided amongst the Directors in such proportion and manner as the Board may determine and in default of determination equally.

Art. 102.- If any Director shall be called upon to perform extra or special services of any kind, or to travel or go or reside out of Egypt for any business or purposes of the Company he shall be entitled to receive such extra rumneration as the Board (subject to any direction given by the Company in General Meeting) shall determine, and the same shall be charged as part of the ordinary working expenses of the Company.

Art 103. — The qualification of a Director shall be the holding in his own right alone, and not jointly with any other person, of shares or stock of the Company of the nominal amount of £200, and this qualification shall be required as well of the first Directors as of all future Directors. A Director may act before obtaining his qualification, but if not already qualified he shall obtain his qualification within two months after his appointment or in default his office shall be vacated. If a Director at any time after the expiration of two months from the date of his appointment cease to hold his qualification his office shall be vacated. A person vacating office under this Article shall be incapable of being re-appointed a Director until he shall have obtained his qualification.

Art. 114. — The Directors may from time to time appoint one or more of their number to be Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period of office and may from time time remove dismissary Managing Director from office and appoint another in his place.
Art. 116 — The remuneration of a Managing Director shall be fixed by the Directors and may be by way of salary, commission, participation in profits, or all or any of these modes.
The Directors are subscribing for and will be allotted Deferred Shares as follows : —
Robert Scott 5,000, Neghib Eid 3,000, Jean Joannides 9,000, Henri Steinmann 1,000. Akhnnukh Fanons 1,000.

The contents of the Memorandum of Association of the Company, with the names, addresses, and descriptions of the signatories, and the number of shares subscribed for by them, is printed in the fold, and forms part of this Proscetus.

The Company has entered into an agreement, dated the fiftteenth day of January 1907 with Neghib Eid under which he underwrites 100 000 Ordinary Shares of the Company in consideration of a carb commission of five per cent.

In addition to the above mentioned underwriting contract a contract dated the fifteenth day of January 1907 between the Company and the said Robert Scott has been entered into for the appointment of the latter as Managing Director and providing for his remuneration as such.
The Company will pay a brokerage of threepence per share on all allotments made on applications made by the public bearing brokers' or bankers' stamp.

A print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company and copies of the above mentioned contracts can be seen at the offices of the Company in Cairo and of their legal adviser in Alexandria during usual business hours at any time before the closing of the subscription list.
By the Article the Capital can be increased to by a simple resolution of the Board.
Applications for shares should be made on the accompanying form and be forwarded to the Company's Bankers with a oblique for the amount payable on application.

If an allotment is not made the application money will be returned in fall, and where the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited towards, be amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to the applicant Failuer, to pay any instalments when due will render all previous payments liable to forfeiture.
Prospectuses and Application Forms can be obtained at the offices the Company in Cairo and the offices of the Bankers, in Cairo and Alexandria.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Capital Social - Le capital social primitivement fixd a douze millions cinq cent mills francs a porte aquinze millions de francs en Juillet 1905 At ensuite a vingt-cinq millions de francs par la creation de quarante mille actions entierement liberees de frs. 250 chacune , dont font partie let trente mille titres mis en souscription publique.

II a ete en outre cinq mille parts de fondateurs dont le nombra a ete porte successivement a cinq mille cinq cents at a sept mills cinq cents lors des augmentations de capital susdites et ce conformement a 1'article 7 des Statuts da la societe.

Sur les mille parts de fondateurs crees actuellement cinq cents ont servi a remunerer divers concourse financiers, cirq cents at a retribuerele Syndicat de banquiers qui a garantil l'augmentation de capital et qui assume tons les frais d'emission. Les mille parts restant a la souche pourront etre utilisees par le Conseil d'Administration pour en fair nlterienrement le meilleur usage dans l'interet de la Societe.
Le nombra defnitif des parts de fondateurs reste ainsi fixe a sent mille cinq cents at ce nombre ne pourra jamais etre depasse mems par voie de modification anx statuts.
Ces parts de fondateurs ont ete divisees en dixemes.
OBJET SOCIAl- Ainsi quisil est dit a l'article 4 des Statuts, la Societe a pour objet de

faire pour elle meme, en participation ou pour compte de ters toutes operations de banque et de finance, ainsi quetontes operations commerciales, agricoles, immobilieres et industrilles qui pourraient s'y rattacher.
Repartition Des Benefices — L'excedent favorable du bilan, detalcation faite de toutes les charges sociales et amortissementa, sil' y a lieu, constitue, le benefice not de la societe.
Sur ce benefice il est preleve:
1* Cirq pour cent poor la constitution du fonds de reserve. Ce prelevement cease d'etre obligatoire q and la reserve legale aura atient le dixieme du capital social.
Sur l'exedent des benefices il sera attribue:
1' La somme necessaire pour payer aux actions de capital un premier dividende cinq pour cent aux le-moutant appele et verse des actions de capital.
3* Un et demi poor oent a chaque administrateur et un demi pour cent a obsque commissaire.
Le solde sera reparti comme suit:
A. Soixsntedix pour cent aux actions de capital A titre de seoond dividende.
B. Trente poor cent anx parts de fondateurs.
Toutefoi, le conseil d'administation peut
proposer A l'assembles generale un prelevement prealable au profit d'one reserve extraordinaire.
Ce prevement se fera apreles attributions au conseil d'administration et au college des commissaire,.

B. Trente, pour cent aux parts de fondsteurs Toutefois le conseil d'administartion peut proposer a l'assmebles generale un prelevement prealable au profit d'une reserve extraordinaire/ Ce pre evement se fera apres les attributions au conseil d'administartion et au college des commissaires.

En creant, il y a un an et demi environ, la societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce, le groupe promoteur de la Societe avait specialement en vue le development des relations entre l'Egypte et la Belgique en pretant son concoura aux nombreuses sociestes belgo egyptiennes etablies au Caire.

Des le debut de l'installation des bureanx an Caire ce programme a e e mis A execution. Toutefois, 1'importance croissaante des affaires financieres en Egypte a immediatement engage le conseil d'administration a concentrer une grande partie de son activite surles operations de barque proprement dites, notamment l'ouverture de complescourants les avances sur titres et les reports.

Ces operations, tout en ayant ete condnites avec la plus grande prudence, ont donne d'emblee desirant les etendre davantage eat entre en pourparlers avexx la maison Rom Vanderlinden and Co. banquiers au Caire pour la reprise de ses affaires.

Cette fusion a'est faite a la date du ler Janvier 1907. Elle permettra a la Societe e Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce de s'occuper encore plus specialment de toutes les affaires, de barque, d'avances sur titres, de reports et d'execution d'ordies de bourse.

Les divers services de la Societe seront ainsi completes et lui rermettront d'espere pour l'annes qui commence des resultants plus favorables encore que ceux dej tres satisfaissants de son premier exercice social.

On peuts attendre, en effet, a ce que lebilan du premier exercise social, qui sera publie lors de la prochaine assembles generals, accuse un benefice suffisant pour permettre la distribution du dividende statutaire et d'un superdividende, ainsi que l'amortissement de tons les frais de premier establissement de tons les frais de premier e'ablissement et la mise a la reserve d' une somme importante.

Apres une premiere annee aussi satisfaisante on est en droit d'esperer que le developpement normal des affaires, anquel vient s'jonter l'appoint considerable de la reprise des affaires de la maison Rom Vanderlinden & Co. reserveront a la Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerece un avenir brillant.
LE CONSEIL D' ADMINISTRATION.

Des Exemplaires des Statuts de la Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce se trouvent a la disposition des souscripteurs aux bureaux de la Societe au Caire et a la Banque de Reports, de Fonds Publics et de Depots a Anvers. 9-92-2-3

div.head: NAVY CONTRACTS.
div.p: PORT SAID AND SUEZ.

TENDERS are hereby invited for new Contracts for the supply of Fresh Beef, Mutton, Vegetables. Soft Bread, and Water to His Majesty's Ships at Port Said and Suez for twelve months from 1st April 1907.
Each article should be tendered for separately, but the tenders for all the articles offered by any particular firm most be placed on the same Form.
Prices should be quoted in English currency.

Forms of Application can be obtained from the Navy agent. British Consulate General, Port Said, to whom tenders should be sent in duplicate, in sealed envelope, in time to be received not later than the 31st Jannary 1907.
The Admiralty reserve the right of rejecting all or any tenders, and of accepting any portion of a tender.
(Signed) D.A. Cameron,
Navy Agent
British Consulate General, Port 8aid.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourdhui a midi et demie.)
Les valeurs solides sont farmes, l'Agricole a 9 5/8, la National Bank a 28 ¼, l'Union Fonciere a 6 ¼ 5/16, etc.

En hausse la Privilegiee Biere d'Alexandrie a 233 et la Dividende a 130. les Nungovich Hotels a 23 3/16, la Khedivial Mail a 4 13 16. les Splendid Hotels a 4 1/8 le Comptor a 8 1/16 l'ancienne et 7 11/16 la nonvelle, le Banco di Roma a 115, et la Banque d'Orient a 134.

Par contre, les Tramways d'Alexandrie fle hissent a 202 les Privilegees at 35 franks les Dividudes, l'Alexandria Water a 13 9/16, les Joussances Eaux du Caire a 295, les Markets a 30/6, l'Obligation Credit Foucier a 340 l'an cienne et 271 ½ la nouvelle, la Cassa di Soonto a 279 l'ancienne et 274 la nouvelle, l'Anglo-American Nile a 5 9/6, la Nile Land a 17 13/16 l'Ordinary Khadivial Mail a 35/6 la Land Investment a 5 1/8 ex la part de fun dateur Comptoir a 100et a Building a 6 ¼.
Le Levico oldture a 5/8, la Hooker a 1 ¼ et l'United a 1 ¼ acheteurs.
Peu d'affaires et teudance indecise.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

An Stock Exchange, le Consolie anglais a reactionne her de 1/8 a 87 1/8. L'Unifiee s'eat maintenue a 102 1/8. La National Bank a gagne ¼ a 28 ½. L'Agricole, la Dira et la Delta Light on restess inchangees a leurs cours precedent.
A paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptian a retrograde de 4 francs a 776 La Banque d'Atheue a regagne 1 franc a 139.
Ici, nous avons eu, anjourd'hui, un marche passablement anime sur certaines valeurs, et calme mais reativement ferme sur l'ensemble de la cots.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National avance a 28 ¼ 5/16. L'Agrico'e a'esttasses a 9 5/8. Le Comptoir Financier a molli a 8 1/16 1/8 et sa part a 103. La part de la Societe Generale Egyptienne est revenue a 110.
La Daira a faibil a 17 ¼ la Behera a let le Wardan Estate a 7 15/16. L'Immobiliers a progresse a 395. L'Allotment s'est inscrite a 3 ½-9/16; sa part a cloture a 140.
L'action Entreprises Immobilieres et Traveaux est remontee a 17 1/8. La part qui a ete l'objet de transactions continues, a avance a 302.
L'Epargne Immobiliere s'est maintenne a 4; sa part a closure a 290. L'Express Nile est reste a 6 et as part a 370.
Les Jouissances Eaux ont avance a 296 297. Les Automobiles ont fleccchi a 5 13/16 et l'Egyptian Mail a 4 ¾.

Ainsi que nous l'avions prevu, les actions Cairo Suburban Co. (Demerdache) ont ete l'objet d'un bon mouvement, qui les a fait avancer a L.E. 6, acheteurs. On s'attend en Bourse a des ocurs plus eleves, justifies d'ailleurs par les informations que nous avons donnees hier. On trouvers doreuavant la cote journaliere dece titre daus le tableau des cours pubue au verso de notre Circulaire.
Dans le groupe des valerus ho eliers les Nungovich ont gague envrion ½ a 203/13/16 et les Egyptian ¼ a 12 ¾-13/16.

Un fort movement e'est produit sur les Excelsior. On l'attribue, a bon droi, au fairt que le ocneil d'administration touu hier so rs'est montre favorable sux off es lattes tu ne l'ach et du terraiu de la Souve liman Pachs.
es parts, libres, plus legeres et plus negociables, que se porteront vertainement les preferences de la speculation.

Parmi les petities va'eurs, la D la Land s'est mainttenue a 4 3/8 Les Estates se sont raff ermis a 2 11/13 et leur part a 22 5/8 ¾. Les New Egyptian onot ete moins bien tenus a 31 sh 9 3 Rien de partculier a relever sur fes autres titres.
On conside e generalement comme aplani en principle le differuud qui s'etait eleve en cesderniers temps entre le Board de Londres de la De'ta Land et le co nite adminstatif local de cette Societe.

A l'arrives du presi lent du conseil, Sir Auckland Colvin, attendu en Egypte lundi pr chain, le terrain se trouverait, paraltil, pret pour un accord appele a transferer an Caire la gerance des affaires foncieres de la Compagnie et a donner ainsi pleine satisfaction aux "desiderata" des actionnaires egyptiens. Dans cet ordre d'idess, il se coufirne que MM. Raphael Suarez et Harari pache feraient bientut partie du conseil d'administration de la Delta Land.
Pour ce qui est des ventes de terrain projectees la Compagnie aurait decline jusqui'ici toutea les offres particuiere, preferant traiter avec un groupe a dos conditions d'ensemble tres avantageuses.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de la Societe anonyme de Wady Kom Onbo soit conveq etre en assembles generale extraordinaire le 2 Ferrier prochain a 1: h. a. m. au sieze social au Caire. A l'ordre du jour : augmentation du capital de la Societe.

-L'assembles generale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Enterprise and Development Co. sera tenue au sieze social au Caire le ler Mars prochain, a 11 b. a.m. A l'ordre du jour: ranport du conseil, approbation du bilan au 31 Decembre 1906 et fixation du dividende.
-Un dividende interimrade P.E. 23 4/10 sera paye, a partir du 5 Fevrier prochain sur les actions d lere et 2eme emissions du Comppoir Financier et Commerical, a valoir sur l'exercise 1906 1907.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
